block.p: International A2-11 A LIFELINE TO HAITIAN REFUGEES

Challenging the Bush Administration's policy, the House of Representatives passed a bill that would halt the forced return of Haitians who have fled their island. Similar legislation is expected to be considered in the Senate, but lawmakers expect a veto by President Bush. A2
International A2-11 A LIFELINE TO HAITIAN REFUGEES

Challenging the Bush Administration's policy, the House of Representatives passed a bill that would halt the forced return of Haitians who have fled their island. Similar legislation is expected to be considered in the Senate, but lawmakers expect a veto by President Bush. A2
WAR ON DRUGS IS SHORT ON CASH

After a conference on drug control, President Bush and Latin American leaders vowed to intensify their efforts. But the President was unable to satisfy the demands by some nations for more money. A9 U.S. MOVES ON GLOBAL WARMING

The Administration said it was taking steps that would significantly reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, a key factor in global warming. The U.S. also said that it would provide $75 million to developing nations to combat the problem. A6 LEBANON TO ACT ON HOSTAGES

For the first time, the Lebanese Government will make an official effort to secure the release of Western hostages. Prime Minister Karami said a committee would be set up to seek freedom for two Germans. A7 A PEACEFUL NOTE IN YUGOSLAVIA
With many Serbs unhappy over the civil war with Croatia and the damage to Yugoslavia's economy, the President of Serbia struck a conciliatory note in a televised speech. A3 IRAQ VOWS DEFIANCE

Baghdad says it will not cooperate with efforts to eliminate its weapons of mass destruction unless the U.N. Security Council relaxes its trade embargo, a U.N. official said. A8 A diverse group of Iraqi opposition leaders struggles to find unity. A8 GERMANY-CZECHOSLOVAKIA PACT
A treaty was signed with the aim of laying to rest the ghost of the 1938 Munich agreement that led to Czechoslovakia's dismemberment by Nazi Germany. A5 BRAND-NEW MARKET IN MOSCOW

An urban real-estate market is suddenly emerging, with transactions often taking place in hard currency. A new law is making it easy for people to own their apartments -- and sell them, too. A10 Fears ease as short-range nuclear weapons go to Russia. A10 DEFENDING THE QUEEN'S HONOR

British politicians and Prime Minister Keating of Australia exchanged verbal salvos over what some Britons and Australians say was Mr. Keating's rude behavior toward Queen Elizabeth. A11 WAITING IN THE DESERT

A vast tent city has sprung up in the Western Sahara as tens of thousands of people gather to take part in a referendum on the region's future. They could have a long wait. A3 Robben Island Journal: Can a penal colony be a tourist attraction? A4 National A12-19 TAX BALL TOSSED TO SENATE

House Democrats barely held together in the first tax skirmish of the election year, passing a middle-class tax cut that instantly became a political football for both parties. A1 ASPIN'S PENTAGON PLAN GAINS

Representative Les Aspin's plan to cut the military budget by about twice as much as the White House wants next year gained ground when a House panel proposed shifting $15 billion from the Pentagon to other programs. A12 UNITED WAY CHIEF RESIGNS

William Aramony stepped down from his job as president of the United Way of America, pursued by revelations of high expense-account living and questionable management practices. A1 QUAYLE CALLS NEW YORK FAILURE
Vice President Quayle came to New York and depicted the city as proof of the failure of the welfare state and liberal economic theories. A1 CANDIDATES EXTEND CLAWS

As the campaign trail grew rougher and shorter, any semblance of collegiality disappeared in the Democratic race, and the Republican primary struggle became, if anything, even rougher. A1 IN SOUTH, MORE THAN ONE ISSUE
In the South, the campaign is being shaped by issues of culture and character, war and manners, race and regional ties. A17 CLINTON'S PLENTIFUL TROUBLES

Political Memo: With each of his foes able to claim success at the polls, Gov. Bill Clinton faced yet another mini-crisis, this time involving unwise remarks made into an open microphone. A16 Jesse Jackson responded to Bill Clinton's "intemperate remarks." A17 The Bush-Buchanan war in Georgia took on a bitter edge. A16 Backers of Sen. Jesse Helms agreed to limits on campaigning. A18 COLORADO FAVORING TSONGAS
Colorado residents, who hold a primary Tuesday, showed a surprising amount of support for Paul Tsongas in opinion polls. A16 A COMPACT COMPACT DISK BOX

Responding to environmental concern, the recording industry said it would replace the long cardboard or plastic display boxes in which it sells compact disks with packaging no bigger than the small plastic container that holds the disk. A1 PROFESSOR CHALLENGES HARVARD

Prof. Derrick Bell, who took a leave of absence from Harvard Law School last year to protest the school's lack of a tenured black woman professor, asked Harvard to let him extend his leave to continue his protest. A12 CREATING CORPORATE SCHOOLS

Chris Whittle, the media entrepreneur, hired a seven-person team to try to create a network of 200 corporate-owned elementary and secondary schools by 1995. A19 A mouse model for Alzheimer's disease isn't, scientists said. A13 The U.S. seized a yacht carrying 85 illegal Chinese immigrants. A12 Law Page B7 Canada's supreme court upholds the country's anti-pornography law.
Metropolitan Digest, B1 DINKINS SCRAMBLES ON BOND SALE

In a successful bid to keep New York City's credit rating from being lowered before a bond sale next week, the Dinkins administration said yesterday that it would greatly reduce its plans for borrowing money to help keep the city budget balanced over the next four years. A1 FERNANDEZ SEEKS TO CALM FEARS

A day after two students were shot to death at Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez sought to calm fears and dampen anger by fashioning a plan to expand the use of metal detectors at the city's most troubled schools. A1 Business Digest, D1 Editorials/Op-Ed A30-31 Editorials A30 Stay what course? Gunplay in the schools. Hold the cheers on Haiti. Topics: Promising start. Letters A30 A. M. Rosenthal: After Saddam, what? A31 Leslie H. Gelb: Who loves Israel? A31 Robert Coover: Sex, stars and leap years. A31 Harvey L. Weinberg: Subway cheating? Hey, it's legal. A31 Weekend C1-32 Dining oases for shoppers. C1 You've seen the movie, now read the book. C1 Sports B8-13 Obituaries B6 S. I. Hayakawa, a U.S. Senator from California.
